I'm bringing this up in response to recent talk about how to graph
networks and know where to put nodes and tell what links are
recurrent.  In Mat Buckland's book chapter on NEAT he describes a much
better method than I used for determining both the layer of various
nodes, and whether connections are recurrent:

The idea is that you have a "splitlevel" for each node, which is a
number between 0 and 1.  Inputs are 0 and outputs are 1 by definition.
 Whenever a link is split by an add-link mutation, the new node
receives a split level halfway between the splitlevels of the innode
and outnode of the connection.  Then, if a connection is added, if the
splitlevel of its innode is greater than that of its outnode, you know
to consider it recurrent!  Quite simple and computationally cheap! 
And of course to know what layer the node should be in in a graph, you
just check its splitlevel.

The one thing I haven't reasoned through for myself is whether
crossover can screw up the appropriate splitlevels in any special
cases.  It doesn't seem so at first thought, but I haven't verified
this for myself so if anyone knows better that would be interesting. 
Otherwise, I think this is the most convenient and efficient way to do
this.

ken
